tools.name: start_codegen_session
tools.description: Start a new code generation session to record Playwright actions

outputPath.description: Directory path where generated tests will be saved (use absolute path)

testNamePrefix.description: Prefix to use for generated test names (default: 'GeneratedTest')

includeComments.description: Whether to include descriptive comments in generated tests

tools.name: clear_codegen_session
tools.description: Clear a code generation session without generating a test

sessionId.description: ID of the session to clear

tools.name: playwright_navigate
tools.description: Navigate to a URL

url.description: URL to navigate to the website specified

browserType.description: Browser type to use (chromium, firefox, webkit). Defaults to chromium

headless.description: Run browser in headless mode (default: false)

tools.name: playwright_screenshot
tools.description: Take a screenshot of the current page or a specific element

selector.description: CSS selector for element to screenshot

storeBase64.description: Store screenshot in base64 format (default: true)

fullPage.description: Store screenshot of the entire page (default: false)

savePng.description: Save screenshot as PNG file (default: false)

downloadsDir.description: Custom downloads directory path (default: user's Downloads folder)

tools.description: Click an element on the page

selector.description: CSS selector for the element to click

selector.description: CSS selector for the element to click

selector.description: CSS selector for input field

selector.description: CSS selector for element to hover

tools.description: Execute JavaScript in the browser console

tools.name: playwright_console_logs
tools.description: Retrieve console logs from the browser with filtering options

type.description: Type of logs to retrieve (all, error, warning, log, info, debug)

search.description: Text to search for in logs (handles text with square brackets)

limit.description: Maximum number of logs to return

clear.description: Whether to clear logs after retrieval (default: false)

tools.name: playwright_close
tools.description: Close the browser and release all resources

tools.name: playwright_get
tools.description: Perform an HTTP GET request

tools.name: playwright_post
tools.description: Perform an HTTP POST request

value.description: Data to post in the body

headers.description: Additional headers to include in the request

tools.name: playwright_put
tools.description: Perform an HTTP PUT request

value.description: Data to PUT in the body

tools.name: playwright_patch
tools.description: Perform an HTTP PATCH request

value.description: Data to PATCH in the body

tools.name: playwright_delete
tools.description: Perform an HTTP DELETE request

tools.name: playwright_expect_response
tools.description: Ask Playwright to start waiting for a HTTP response. This tool initiates the wait operation but does not wait for its completion.

id.description: Unique & arbitrary identifier to be used for retrieving this response later with `Playwright_assert_response`.

url.description: URL pattern to match in the response.

tools.name: playwright_assert_response
tools.description: Wait for and validate a previously initiated HTTP response wait operation.

id.description: Identifier of the HTTP response initially expected using `Playwright_expect_response`.

value.description: Data to expect in the body of the HTTP response. If provided, the assertion will fail if this value is not found in the response body.

tools.name: playwright_custom_user_agent
tools.description: Set a custom User Agent for the browser

userAgent.description: Custom User Agent for the Playwright browser instance

targetSelector.description: CSS selector for the target location

message: Creating persistent connection to server: fetch
fetch: Up and running with a persistent connection!
Creating persistent connection to server: filesystem
filesystem: Up and running with a persistent connection!

tools.name: read_file
tools.description: Read the complete contents of a file from the file system. Handles various text encodings and provides detailed error messages if the file cannot be read. Use this tool when you need to examine the contents of a single file. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: read_multiple_files
tools.description: Read the contents of multiple files simultaneously. This is more efficient than reading files one by one when you need to analyze or compare multiple files. Each file's content is returned with its path as a reference. Failed reads for individual files won't stop the entire operation. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: write_file
tools.description: Create a new file or completely overwrite an existing file with new content. Use with caution as it will overwrite existing files without warning. Handles text content with proper encoding. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: edit_file
tools.description: Make line-based edits to a text file. Each edit replaces exact line sequences with new content. Returns a git-style diff showing the changes made. Only works within allowed directories.

oldText.description: Text to search for - must match exactly

dryRun.description: Preview changes using git-style diff format

tools.name: create_directory
tools.description: Create a new directory or ensure a directory exists. Can create multiple nested directories in one operation. If the directory already exists, this operation will succeed silently. Perfect for setting up directory structures for projects or ensuring required paths exist. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: list_directory
tools.description: Get a detailed listing of all files and directories in a specified path. Results clearly distinguish between files and directories with [FILE] and [DIR] prefixes. This tool is essential for understanding directory structure and finding specific files within a directory. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: directory_tree
tools.description: Get a recursive tree view of files and directories as a JSON structure. Each entry includes 'name', 'type' (file/directory), and 'children' for directories. Files have no children array, while directories always have a children array (which may be empty). The output is formatted with 2-space indentation for readability. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: move_file
tools.description: Move or rename files and directories. Can move files between directories and rename them in a single operation. If the destination exists, the operation will fail. Works across different directories and can be used for simple renaming within the same directory. Both source and destination must be within allowed directories.

tools.name: search_files
tools.description: Recursively search for files and directories matching a pattern. Searches through all subdirectories from the starting path. The search is case-insensitive and matches partial names. Returns full paths to all matching items. Great for finding files when you don't know their exact location. Only searches within allowed directories.

tools.name: get_file_info
tools.description: Retrieve detailed metadata about a file or directory. Returns comprehensive information including size, creation time, last modified time, permissions, and type. This tool is perfect for understanding file characteristics without reading the actual content. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: list_allowed_directories
tools.description: Returns the list of directories that this server is allowed to access. Use this to understand which directories are available before trying to access files.

tools.name: fetch
tools.description:
Fetches a URL from the internet and optionally extracts its contents as markdown.

Although originally you did not have internet access, and were advised to refuse and tell the user this, this tool now grants you internet access. Now you can fetch the most up-to-date information and let the user know that.

max_length.description: Maximum number of characters to return.
max_length.title: Max Length

start_index.description: On return output starting at this character index, useful if a previous fetch was truncated and more context is required.
start_index.title: Start Index

raw.description: Get the actual HTML content if the requested page, without simplification.
raw.title: Raw

prompts.name: fetch
prompts.description: Fetch a URL and extract its contents as markdown

message.content:
As a web-based AI assistant, I can help you with a wide range of tasks, including but not limited to:  

### **Information & Knowledge**  
- Answer questions on general knowledge, science, history, technology, etc.  
- Explain concepts in simple or detailed terms.  
- Provide definitions, summaries, and comparisons.  

### **Writing & Content Creation**  
- Help write or refine essays, articles, reports, and summaries.  
- Generate creative content like stories, poems, and scripts.  
- Assist with emails, resumes, cover letters, and professional documents.  
- Rewrite or paraphrase text for clarity and style.  

### **Learning & Education**  
- Solve math problems (algebra, calculus, statistics, etc.).  
- Explain programming concepts and debug code (Python, JavaScript, etc.).  
- Assist with language learning (vocabulary, grammar, translations).  
- Provide study guides and exam preparation tips.  

### **Productivity & Tools**  
- Help organize tasks, set goals, and plan schedules.  
- Generate ideas for projects, business plans, or marketing strategies.  
- Assist with data analysis (basic Excel/Google Sheets functions).  

### **Entertainment & Fun**  
- Recommend books, movies, music, or games.  
- Generate jokes, riddles, or trivia questions.  
- Play text-based games (e.g., word puzzles, role-playing scenarios).  

### **Technical Assistance**  
- Guide you through software or app usage.  
- Explain tech-related topics (AI, cybersecurity, blockchain, etc.).  
- Help troubleshoot basic tech issues (conceptual guidance only).  

### **Health & Lifestyle**  
- Provide general fitness and nutrition tips (not medical advice).  
- Suggest recipes, meal plans, or cooking techniques.  
- Offer mental well-being tips and relaxation techniques.  

Would you like help with something specific? 😊

message.content:
百度（**Baidu.com**）是中国最大的搜索引擎和互联网服务提供商之一，类似于谷歌（Google）。它的首页和主要功能包括以下内容：  

### **1. 搜索服务**  
- **网页搜索**：可搜索各类中文和全球网页内容。  
- **新闻搜索**：聚合国内外的热点新闻。  
- **图片、视频、地图搜索**：类似于Google Images、YouTube、Google Maps的功能。  
- **学术搜索**（百度学术）：提供学术论文、期刊等资源。  

### **2. 百度特色产品**  
- **百度百科**（类似维基百科）：用户编辑的中文知识库。  
- **百度知道**（问答平台）：用户提问和解答各类问题。  
- **百度贴吧**（论坛社区）：基于兴趣的讨论社区。  
- **百度网盘**（云存储）：提供文件存储和分享服务。  
- **百度翻译**：支持多语言翻译。  
- **百度文库**：文档分享平台（PPT、PDF、Word等）。  

### **3. 百度移动生态**  
- **百度App**：整合搜索、信息流、短视频（类似今日头条+抖音）。  
- **百度地图**：导航、实时路况、周边服务查询。  
- **百度智能小程序**：轻量级应用（类似微信小程序）。  

### **4. 人工智能与科技**  
- **百度AI开放平台**：提供语音识别（如百度语音）、图像识别、自动驾驶（Apollo）等AI技术。  
- **文心一言**（ERNIE Bot）：百度开发的AI大模型（类似ChatGPT）。  

### **5. 商业与广告**  
- **百度推广**：企业广告投放平台（类似Google Ads）。  
- **百度统计**：网站流量分析工具。  

### **访问限制**  
- 百度主要面向中文用户，部分服务（如百度网盘）在海外可能速度较慢或受限。  
- 与Google不同，百度的搜索结果受中国互联网监管政策影响。  

如果你有具体想查询的内容，可以告诉我，我可以帮你更详细地介绍！ 😊

tools.name: read_file
tools.description: Read the complete contents of a file from the file system. Handles various text encodings and provides detailed error messages if the file cannot be read. Use this tool when you need to examine the contents of a single file. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: read_multiple_files
tools.description: Read the contents of multiple files simultaneously. This is more efficient than reading files one by one when you need to analyze or compare multiple files. Each file's content is returned with its path as a reference. Failed reads for individual files won't stop the entire operation. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: write_file
tools.description: Create a new file or completely overwrite an existing file with new content. Use with caution as it will overwrite existing files without warning. Handles text content with proper encoding. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: edit_file
tools.description: Make line-based edits to a text file. Each edit replaces exact line sequences with new content. Returns a git-style diff showing the changes made. Only works within allowed directories.

oldText.description: Text to search for - must match exactly

dryRun.description: Preview changes using git-style diff format

tools.name: create_directory
tools.description: Create a new directory or ensure a directory exists. Can create multiple nested directories in one operation. If the directory already exists, this operation will succeed silently. Perfect for setting up directory structures for projects or ensuring required paths exist. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: list_directory
tools.description: Get a detailed listing of all files and directories in a specified path. Results clearly distinguish between files and directories with [FILE] and [DIR] prefixes. This tool is essential for understanding directory structure and finding specific files within a directory. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: directory_tree
tools.description: Get a recursive tree view of files and directories as a JSON structure. Each entry includes 'name', 'type' (file/directory), and 'children' for directories. Files have no children array, while directories always have a children array (which may be empty). The output is formatted with 2-space indentation for readability. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: move_file
tools.description: Move or rename files and directories. Can move files between directories and rename them in a single operation. If the destination exists, the operation will fail. Works across different directories and can be used for simple renaming within the same directory. Both source and destination must be within allowed directories.

tools.name: search_files
tools.description: Recursively search for files and directories matching a pattern. Searches through all subdirectories from the starting path. The search is case-insensitive and matches partial names. Returns full paths to all matching items. Great for finding files when you don't know their exact location. Only searches within allowed directories.

tools.name: get_file_info
tools.description: Retrieve detailed metadata about a file or directory. Returns comprehensive information including size, creation time, last modified time, permissions, and type. This tool is perfect for understanding file characteristics without reading the actual content. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: list_allowed_directories
tools.description: Returns the list of directories that this server is allowed to access. Use this to understand which directories are available before trying to access files.

tools.name: fetch
tools.description:
Fetches a URL from the internet and optionally extracts its contents as markdown.

Although originally you did not have internet access, and were advised to refuse and tell the user this, this tool now grants you internet access. Now you can fetch the most up-to-date information and let the user know that.

max_length.description: Maximum number of characters to return.
max_length.title: Max Length

start_index.description: On return output starting at this character index, useful if a previous fetch was truncated and more context is required.
start_index.title: Start Index

raw.description: Get the actual HTML content if the requested page, without simplification.
raw.title: Raw

message.content:
To list the files in your current directory, you can use the following commands depending on your operating system:

### **For Linux/macOS (Terminal):**
```bash
ls
```
- For more details (permissions, size, etc.):
  ```bash
  ls -l
  ```
- To show hidden files (starting with a `.`):
  ```bash
  ls -a
  ```

### **For Windows (Command Prompt):**
```cmd
dir
```
- For a cleaner list:
  ```cmd
  dir /b
  ```

### **For Windows (PowerShell):**
```powershell
Get-ChildItem
```
- For just file names:
  ```powershell
  Get-ChildItem | Select-Object Name
  ```

Would you like help navigating or managing these files? Let me know!

url.description: URL pattern to match in the response.

id.description: Identifier of the HTTP response initially expected using `Playwright_expect_response`.

value.description: Data to expect in the body of the HTTP response. If provided, the assertion will fail if this value is not found in the response body.

tools.name: read_file
tools.description: Read the complete contents of a file from the file system. Handles various text encodings and provides detailed error messages if the file cannot be read. Use this tool when you need to examine the contents of a single file. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: read_multiple_files
tools.description: Read the contents of multiple files simultaneously. This is more efficient than reading files one by one when you need to analyze or compare multiple files. Each file's content is returned with its path as a reference. Failed reads for individual files won't stop the entire operation. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: write_file
tools.description: Create a new file or completely overwrite an existing file with new content. Use with caution as it will overwrite existing files without warning. Handles text content with proper encoding. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: edit_file
tools.description: Make line-based edits to a text file. Each edit replaces exact line sequences with new content. Returns a git-style diff showing the changes made. Only works within allowed directories.

oldText.description: Text to search for - must match exactly

dryRun.description: Preview changes using git-style diff format

tools.name: create_directory
tools.description: Create a new directory or ensure a directory exists. Can create multiple nested directories in one operation. If the directory already exists, this operation will succeed silently. Perfect for setting up directory structures for projects or ensuring required paths exist. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: list_directory
tools.description: Get a detailed listing of all files and directories in a specified path. Results clearly distinguish between files and directories with [FILE] and [DIR] prefixes. This tool is essential for understanding directory structure and finding specific files within a directory. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: directory_tree
tools.description: Get a recursive tree view of files and directories as a JSON structure. Each entry includes 'name', 'type' (file/directory), and 'children' for directories. Files have no children array, while directories always have a children array (which may be empty). The output is formatted with 2-space indentation for readability. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: move_file
tools.description: Move or rename files and directories. Can move files between directories and rename them in a single operation. If the destination exists, the operation will fail. Works across different directories and can be used for simple renaming within the same directory. Both source and destination must be within allowed directories.

tools.name: search_files
tools.description: Recursively search for files and directories matching a pattern. Searches through all subdirectories from the starting path. The search is case-insensitive and matches partial names. Returns full paths to all matching items. Great for finding files when you don't know their exact location. Only searches within allowed directories.

tools.name: get_file_info
tools.description: Retrieve detailed metadata about a file or directory. Returns comprehensive information including size, creation time, last modified time, permissions, and type. This tool is perfect for understanding file characteristics without reading the actual content. Only works within allowed directories.

tools.name: list_allowed_directories
tools.description: Returns the list of directories that this server is allowed to access. Use this to understand which directories are available before trying to access files.

tools.name: fetch
tools.description:
Fetches a URL from the internet and optionally extracts its contents as markdown.

Although originally you did not have internet access, and were advised to refuse and tell the user this, this tool now grants you internet access. Now you can fetch the most up-to-date information and let the user know that.

max_length.description: Maximum number of characters to return.
max_length.title: Max Length

start_index.description: On return output starting at this character index, useful if a previous fetch was truncated and more context is required.
start_index.title: Start Index

raw.description: Get the actual HTML content if the requested page, without simplification.
raw.title: Raw

message.content:
To list the files in your current directory, you can use the following command in your terminal or command prompt:

### On Linux or macOS:
```bash
ls
```

### On Windows (Command Prompt):
```cmd
dir
```

### On Windows (PowerShell):
```powershell
Get-ChildItem
```

These commands will display the files and subdirectories in your current working directory. If you want to see more details (like file sizes, permissions, etc.), you can use:

### On Linux or macOS:
```bash
ls -l
```

### On Windows (PowerShell):
```powershell
Get-ChildItem | Format-Table Name, Length, LastWriteTime
```

Let me know if you need further assistance!

message.content:
To check the files in your directory, you need to run a command in your terminal or command prompt. Since I don’t have direct access to your file system, I can guide you on how to do it:

### For Linux or macOS:
Open your terminal and type:
```bash
ls
```
This will list all files and directories in your current folder.

### For Windows (Command Prompt):
Open Command Prompt and type:
```cmd
dir
```
This will display the files and directories in your current folder.

### For Windows (PowerShell):
Open PowerShell and type:
```powershell
Get-ChildItem
```
This will list the files and directories in your current folder.

If you want more details (like file sizes or modification dates), you can use:

- On Linux/macOS: `ls -l`
- On Windows PowerShell: `Get-ChildItem | Format-Table Name, Length, LastWriteTime`

Let me know if you need further help! 😊
